conclusion: Object A has a horizontal line indicating constant acceleration a₀.
Object B has an oblique line through the origin indicating acceleration grows linearly with time, a_B(t)=k t.
The two lines cross at t = t₁, so a_B(t₁)=a₀.
The graph states t₂ = 2 t₁; this will not be needed for the question asked.
Express the slope k for object B as k = a₀ / t₁.
Both objects start from rest at t = 0: v_A(0)=v_B(0)=0.
Velocity of object A at t₁ is v_A(t₁)= a₀ t₁ due to constant acceleration.
Velocity of object B at t₁ is calculated as v_B(t₁)= (a₀ t₁)/2 using integration.
Compare the velocities: v_A(t₁)= a₀ t₁ and v_B(t₁)= ½ a₀ t₁, showing v_A(t₁)=2 v_B(t₁).
Final answer: NO. At time t₁ object A is moving twice as fast as object B (v_A = 2 v_B).
